Definition / general

* Chronic, rare, immune mediated ulcerative condition that mainly affects mucous membranes* Autoantibodies target the ΔNp63α isoform of p63, a nuclear protein in basal keratinocytes of stratified squamous epithelium

Essential features

* Clinically and histopathologically overlaps with erosive lichen planus ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:386](30374883))* Highly refractory to corticosteroids and standard erosive lichen planus management* Direct immunofluorescence or indirect immunofluorescence testing is the only definitive way to distinguish erosive oral lichen planus from chronic ulcerative stomatitis (CUS)* Any oral site may be involved, with the buccal mucosa, gingiva and tongue most commonly affected* Direct immunofluorescence: speckled, finely granular pattern (stratified epithelium specific antinuclear antibody [SES ANA] pattern) of IgG antibody in basal and parabasal cell nuclei of keratinocytes ([Oral Dis 2019;25:1465](30457193), [Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:386](30374883), [Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2003;96:718](14676763))* Responds well to hydroxychloroquine ([Oral Dis 2019;25:1465](30457193), [Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:386](30374883), [Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2007;104:194](17560144))

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [K12.1](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/K00-K95/K00-K14/K12-/K12.1) - other forms of stomatitis

Epidemiology

* Predominantly affects White females (> 90% of cases) ([Oral Maxillofac Surg Clin North Am 2023;35:189](36805899))* Common in the fifth and sixth decades of life

Sites

* Primarily affects the oral cavity, with the buccal mucosa (43.75%), gingiva (38.75%) and tongue (22.5%) most commonly involved ([Schmidt: Diseases of the Oral Mucosa, 1st Edition, 2022](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/3030828034/pathologyoutl-20))* Other affected sites include the palate, lingual mucosa, lower lip and cheek ([Oral Dis 2019;25:1465](30457193))* Extraoral involvement occurs in 22.5% of cases ([Schmidt: Diseases of the Oral Mucosa, 1st Edition, 2022](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/3030828034/pathologyoutl-20))

Pathophysiology

* Autoantibodies bind to ΔNp63α, interfering with its DNA binding function and disrupting the transcription of genes essential for epithelial integrity ([Oral Dis 2008;14:383](18593454))* Autoantibody interference affects α6β4 integrin expression, a key component of hemidesmosomal attachment of basal cells to laminin 332 in the basement membrane, leading to loss of epithelial adhesion and migration ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2003;96:718](14676763))* p63 gene (located on chromosome 3q27) belongs to the *TP53* family, which includes p53 and p73, sharing functional domains involved in transcription regulation* ΔNp63α isoform is predominantly expressed in squamous epithelia and plays a crucial role in epithelial development and differentiation ([Int J Mol Sci 2022;23:13772](36430253))
        + It regulates epithelial differentiation, adhesion and proliferation, ensuring the integrity and survival of stratified squamous epithelial cells

Etiology

* Chronic ulcerative stomatitis autoantibodies target ΔNp63α, a nuclear protein normally found in basal keratinocytes of stratified squamous epithelium ([Oral Dis 2008;14:383](18593454))* Some theories suggest that chronic inflammation exposes intranuclear antigens, triggering a B cell response and autoantibody production, similar to mechanisms in oral lichen planus and other autoimmune diseases* Experimental and clinical data support chronic ulcerative stomatitis as an organ specific autoimmune disease, with hydroxychloroquine demonstrating efficacy by modulating B cell responses

Clinical features

* Array of clinical presentations similar to oral lichen planus and autoimmune vesiculobullous diseases* Progressive, painful, nonhealing, ulcerative erosive lesions or vesicles with or without desquamative gingivitis ([Oral Maxillofac Surg Clin North Am 2023;35:189](36805899))* Hypertrophic areas, especially on the dorsal tongue, mimicking hypertrophic lichen planus* Ulcers are surrounded by erythematous zones and streaky keratosis, resembling oral lichen planus but lacking classic Wickham striae ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:386](30374883))* Ulcers heal without scarring, with alternating periods of severity and migration across the oral mucosa* Patients may experience systemic symptoms, including fatigue, weight loss, dry mouth, mood changes and sleep disturbances

Diagnosis

* Diagnosis made on routine H&E histological examination and biopsy for direct immunofluorescence ([Oral Maxillofac Surg Clin North Am 2023;35:189](36805899))* Direct immunofluorescence is gold standard for diagnosis* Serum studies using indirect immunofluorescence on guinea pig esophagus substrates reveal high titers of circulating IgG antibodies bound to epithelial nuclei in the basal layer in the SES ANA pattern

Laboratory

* Enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA): detects specific IgG antibodies against ΔNp63α protein (80% sensitivity and 75% specificity) ([Oral Dis 2010;16:151](19682320))

Prognostic factors

* Overall prognosis is good* Lesions heal and regress uneventfully with appropriate treatment* Complications, mainly from medication adverse effects, may include retinopathy, neuromuscular issues and hematologic disorders ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2003;96:718](14676763), [J Oral Pathol Med 2017;46:859](28186659))

Case reports

* 40 - 81 year old White women presented with painful ulcers, mucosal irritation and oral dryness, primarily affecting the gingiva, tongue and buccal mucosa ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2007;104:194](17560144))* 54 year old White woman presented with a 2 - 3 year history of stomatitis and dry mouth ([J Periodontol 2000;71:104](10695945))* 55 year old Caucasian man presented with painful intraoral ulcers causing difficulty in eating for ~2 weeks ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2020;130:e152](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2020.04.204))* 61 - 85 year old men and women presented with presumed erosive lichen lesions in the oral cavity ([J Cutan Pathol 2018;45:927](30159907))

Treatment

* Hydroxychloroquine limits disease progression, keeping patients generally asymptomatic
  + Dosage of 200 mg/day helps improve the condition in the majority of cases ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2003;96:718](14676763))+ Effective initially but not suitable for long term use due to gastrointestinal and ocular side effects

Gross description

* Thin wedge of white-tan surface epithelium with underlying tan-gray connective tissue* Epithelium occasionally ulcerated or separated from underlying connective tissue

Frozen section description

* Frozen sections must be obtained from a perilesional area with an intact surface mucosa* Specimen is often composed of superficial stratified squamous epithelium and underlying fibrous connective tissue* Frequently show atrophic epithelium with few sawtoothed rete ridges or a somewhat flat basement membrane, with or without surface ulceration or subepithelial clefting ([J Cutan Pathol 2018;45:927](30159907))* Superficial lamina propria demonstrates an intense band-like infiltrate composed mainly of lymphocytes; partial destruction of the basal cell layer may be observed

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Ulcerated specimens often show atrophic epithelium with few sawtoothed rete ridges and eosinophilic coagulum along the basement membrane zone ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:386](30374883))* Numerous eosinophilic Civatte bodies (necrotic keratinocytes) are present within the epithelium* Significant interface stomatitis composed mainly of lymphocytes and plasma cells* Leukocytic exocytosis may be present; partial basal cell layer destruction may be observed

Immunofluorescence description

* Speckled, finely granular IgG staining in basal and parabasal keratinocyte nuclei ([Head Neck Pathol 2019;13:386](30374883))* Fibrinogen along the basement membrane may or may not be seen* IgA and C3 may also be observed in a similar pattern to IgG ([J Cutan Pathol 2018;45:927](30159907))* Occasional traces of IgM may be present ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2015;120:622](26337216))

Sample pathology report

* Oral mucosa, incisional biopsy:
  + Routine histopathology and direct immunofluorescent antibody studies compatible with chronic ulcerative stomatitis (see comment)+ Comment: On H&E, there is atrophy of the stratified squamous epithelium and a lichenoid pattern of inflammation at the epithelium / connective tissue interface. Also noted is a focal subepithelial separation. Direct immunofluorescence shows a speckled and granular pattern at the basal and parabasal cell layers, with a nuclear distribution for IgG and negativity for C3, IgM, IgA and fibrinogen.

Differential diagnosis

* [Erosive lichen planus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitylichenplanus.html):
  + T cell mediated autoimmune disease+ Epithelial atrophy with Civatte bodies+ Subepithelial band of lymphocytes+ Direct immunofluorescence shows shaggy **fibrinogen** deposition at the basement membrane zone (BMZ) or **C3** at BMZ and [IgM](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsIgA.html) positive colloid bodies ([Mod Pathol 2017;30:S54](28060366))+ Clinically, lesions often respond to corticosteroid therapy ([Oral Maxillofac Surg Clin North Am 2023;35:189](36805899))* [Mucous membrane pemphigoid](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/oralcavitypemphigoid.html):
    + Subepithelial blistering disease, commonly presenting in the oral cavity ([Oral Maxillofac Surg Clin North Am 2023;35:203](37019505))+ Affects middle aged to older adults+ Slight female predominance+ Characterized by ulcers, with or without blood blister formation+ Positive Nikolsky sign+ Direct immunofluorescence reveals [IgG](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsIgA.html), **C3** and / or [IgA](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsIgA.html) positivity at the BMZ ([Oral Maxillofac Surg Clin North Am 2023;35:203](37019505))+ Clinically, lesions often respond to corticosteroid therapy* [Lupus erythematosus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumorlupussle.html):
      + Oral involvement occurs in ~25% of cases+ Most cases have cutaneous involvement or are associated with systemic inflammatory disease+ Histopathology shows a lichenoid pattern, often with perivascular inflammation ([Mod Pathol 2017;30:S54](28060366))+ Direct immunofluorescence reveals a linear band or continuous granular deposition of [IgG](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsIgA.html), [IgM](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsIgA.html), [IgA](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsIgA.html) or **C3** at the basement membrane zone* [Oral lichenoid drug reaction](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumordrugreaction.html):
        + Oral mucosal immunoinflammatory disorder that causes erythematous plaques, vesicles, ulcers or hyperkeratosis in response to medications+ Onset varies after medication initiation+ Commonly associated with NSAIDs, anticonvulsants, antihypertensives, antimalarials and antiretrovirals+ Histologically, a lichenoid infiltrate may extend into the deep lamina propria and show perivascular inflammation+ Infiltrate may be diffuse or mixed with plasma cells and occasionally eosinophils+ Direct immunofluorescence may be negative or show shaggy **fibrinogen** deposition at the BMZ or **C3** at BMZ and [IgM](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsIgA.html) positive colloid bodies ([Mod Pathol 2017;30:S54](28060366))+ Withdrawal of the causative agent may result in improvement within 2 - 8 weeks ([Oral Maxillofac Surg Clin North Am 2023;35:189](36805899))* [Oral lichenoid contact hypersensitivity reaction](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumorallergiccontact.html):
          + Oral mucosal immunoinflammatory disorder causing erythematous plaques, vesicles, ulcers or hyperkeratosis in response to a local agent+ May present with pain, burning or itchiness+ Commonly triggered by mouthwashes, foods, spices (especially cinnamon), gloves, rubber dams and dental materials+ Histologically, lichenoid interface mucositis with mixed inflammation extending into the deep lamina propria and perivascular inflammation+ Direct immunofluorescence may be negative or show features similar to oral lichen planus ([Mod Pathol 2017;30:S54](28060366))+ Resolution typically occurs after eliminating the offending agent* [Oral graft versus host disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumorGVHD.html):
            + Clinical and histopathological presentations may resemble those of oral lichenoid lesions+ Occurs as a result of allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation
